[File: config/src/config/consensus_config.rs] [Constant: MAX_SENDING_BLOCK_TXNS_AFTER_FILTERING] [Integer Overflow] Can an attacker exploit the constant MAX_SENDING_BLOCK_TXNS_AFTER_FILTERING (1800) by manipulating transaction counts to bypass block size limits and cause consensus nodes to process oversized blocks, leading to memory exhaustion or DoS? (High)

[File: config/src/config/consensus_config.rs] [Constant: MAX_SENDING_OPT_BLOCK_TXNS_AFTER_FILTERING] [Configuration Bypass] Can an attacker exploit the difference between MAX_SENDING_OPT_BLOCK_TXNS_AFTER_FILTERING (1000) and MAX_SENDING_BLOCK_TXNS_AFTER_FILTERING (1800) to send larger blocks than intended during optimistic execution, causing execution divergence across validators? (High)

[File: config/src/config/consensus_config.rs] [Constant: MAX_SENDING_BLOCK_TXNS] [Block Size Attack] Can a malicious proposer craft blocks with exactly MAX_SENDING_BLOCK_TXNS (5000) transactions containing expensive operations to cause execution timeouts and halt consensus progress? (High)

[File: config/src/config/consensus_config.rs] [Constant: MAX_RECEIVING_BLOCK_TXNS] [DoS via Large Blocks] Is the calculation '10000.max(2 * MAX_SENDING_BLOCK_TXNS)' in MAX_RECEIVING_BLOCK_TXNS vulnerable to accepting excessively large blocks (20,000+ txns) that could overwhelm validator memory and crash nodes? (Critical)

[File: config/src/config/consensus_config.rs] [Constant: MIN_BLOCK_BYTES_OVERRIDE] [Backpressure Bypass] Can an attacker exploit MIN_BLOCK_BYTES_OVERRIDE (1MB + padding) to craft blocks that bypass backpressure mechanisms by staying just above the threshold, allowing continuous large block submission during network congestion? (Medium)

[File: config/src/config/consensus_config.rs] [Constant: MIN_BLOCK_TXNS_AFTER_FILTERING] [Resource Exhaustion] Can the constant MIN_BLOCK_TXNS_AFTER_FILTERING (DEFEAULT_MAX_BATCH_TXNS * 2) be exploited to force validators to accept minimum block sizes that are still large enough to cause execution bottlenecks? (Medium)

[File: config/src/config/consensus_config.rs] [Field: max_network_channel_size] [Channel Overflow] Can an attacker flood the consensus network channel (max_network_channel_size: 1024) with crafted messages to cause buffer overflow, message dropping, or consensus message loss leading to liveness failure? (High)

[File: config/src/config/consensus_config.rs] [Field: max_sending_block_txns] [Transaction Count Manipulation] Can a Byzantine validator exploit max_sending_block_txns to propose blocks with transaction counts just under the limit but containing extremely expensive transactions, causing execution delays without triggering backpressure? (High)

[File: config/src/config/consensus_config.rs] [Field: max_sending_block_bytes] [Block Size Manipulation] Can an attacker craft transactions that compress well but expand during execution, bypassing max_sending_block_bytes (3MB) checks at proposal time but causing memory exhaustion during execution? (High)

[File: config/src/config/consensus_config.rs] [Field: max_receiving_block_txns vs max_sending_block_txns] [Send/Receive Mismatch] Can an attacker exploit the gap between max_receiving_block_txns and max_sending_block_txns to send blocks that pass receiving checks but violate consensus invariants, causing state divergence? (Critical)

[File: config/src/config/consensus_config.rs] [Field: max_sending_inline_txns] [Inline Transaction Abuse] Can a malicious proposer exploit max_sending_inline_txns (100) to include inline transactions that bypass normal transaction validation, allowing unauthorized operations or double-spending? (Critical)

[File: config/src/config/consensus_config.rs] [Field: max_sending_inline_bytes] [Inline Payload Attack] Can an attacker craft inline payloads approaching max_sending_inline_bytes (200KB) that contain malicious code or exploit deserialization vulnerabilities in consensus nodes? (High)

[File: config/src/config/consensus_config.rs] [Field: max_pruned_blocks_in_mem] [Memory Exhaustion] Can an attacker force the system to maintain max_pruned_blocks_in_mem (100) large blocks in memory simultaneously, causing OOM errors and validator crashes? (High)

[File: config/src/config/consensus_config.rs] [Field: mempool_executed_txn_timeout_ms] [Timeout Manipulation] Can a Byzantine node exploit mempool_executed_txn_timeout_ms (1000ms) by intentionally delaying transaction execution acknowledgments to cause proposers to resend transactions, leading to duplicate execution or state corruption? [File: config/src/config/consensus_config.rs] [Field: round_initial_timeout_ms] [Consensus Timing Attack] Can a malicious validator manipulate round_initial_timeout_ms (1000ms) through local configuration changes to cause premature timeouts and unnecessary view changes, degrading consensus performance? (High)

[File: config/src/config/consensus_config.rs] [Field: round_timeout_backoff_max_exponent] [Unbounded Timeout] Is round_timeout_backoff_max_exponent (6) sufficient to prevent timeout values from growing unbounded during prolonged network issues, or can attackers exploit this to cause permanent consensus stalls? (High)

[File: config/src/config/consensus_config.rs] [Field: sync_only] [Consensus Bypass] Can a validator maliciously set sync_only to true to stop voting on blocks while still receiving committed transactions, potentially breaking quorum requirements and causing liveness failures? (Critical)

[File: config/src/config/consensus_config.rs] [Field: quorum_store_pull_timeout_ms] [Quorum Store DoS] Can an attacker exploit quorum_store_pull_timeout_ms (400ms) by delaying batch delivery to cause proposers to timeout repeatedly, preventing efficient block construction? (Medium)
